title: 114_hr3241
content: The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 aims to establish a framework for each state to provide comprehensive universal health coverage to its residents. This Act includes a waiver for state universal health care under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. A State may apply to the Secretary for a waiver of certain health benefits coverage requirements to implement a State universal health care plan. The application must include a description of the State legislation and program for the waiver. The State must submit a 10-fiscal-year budget plan that is budget neutral for the Federal Government and assure the enactment of specific laws for health benefits coverage. The requirements include various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the Social Security Act, and a waiver application for a State universal health care plan. The State must submit a budget plan for Federal Government approval, including specific laws for health benefits coverage. This involves sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the Social Security Act, and a waiver application for a State universal health care plan. The waiver allows the State to assume responsibility for health coverage under specified Federal health programs. The Secretary shall not spend Federal health funds that would have been used for a program, but provide an alternative means for the State to receive the funds for implementing the State plan under the waiver. The amount will be determined annually, considering the funds that would have been spent under the Federal health program if the waiver did not apply, including premium tax credits, cost-sharing reductions, and small-business credits. The Secretary will consider applications for waivers under the State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015, with regulations for public input and hearings at the State level within 180 days of enactment. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 requires a process for public input, application disclosure, and public notice and comment to ensure compliance with waiver provisions. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 mandates a process for public input, application disclosure, and public notice and comment to ensure compliance with waiver provisions. Additionally, it includes requirements for periodic reports and evaluations by the Secretary regarding waivers granted under the act. The Secretary is also required to annually report to Congress on actions taken with respect to waiver applications and programs. The Secretary may grant a waiver request under subsection (a)(1) if the State plan provides comprehensive health benefits coverage to residents, comparable to what they would have received under the Federal program. The plan must also offer affordable coverage and cost-sharing protections against excessive out-of-pocket spending. The State must provide comprehensive health benefits coverage to residents that is as affordable as the Federal program, cover substantially all residents, be publicly administered by a State agency, and not increase the Federal deficit. The State must provide comprehensive health benefits coverage to residents that is as affordable as the Federal program, cover substantially all residents, be publicly administered by a State agency, and not increase the Federal deficit. A State law is required for actions under a waiver, including implementing the State plan. The Secretary determines the scope of the waiver. The Secretary determines the scope of a waiver granted to a State, with a limitation on waiving only listed Federal laws. The determination must be made within 180 days of receiving the State's application, and if granted, the State is notified of the terms and effectiveness of the waiver. The Secretary notifies the State and Congress if a waiver is denied, and waivers cannot exceed 5 years unless extended by the State. Coordination is ensured for the waiver process. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 mandates coordination among various Secretaries to develop a process for consolidating State waiver processes under different Federal laws. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 requires coordination among Secretaries to ensure consistent administration of regulations and policies related to health care provision and waivers. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 mandates coordination among Secretaries and the Director to streamline waiver applications and avoid duplication of efforts. States can submit a single application for waivers under all relevant provisions, with recommendations for amendments submitted to Congress. The State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 mandates coordination among Secretaries and the Director to streamline waiver applications and avoid duplication of efforts. Recommendations for technical and conforming amendments to law will be submitted to Congress to assist in implementation. Definitions in the act include health benefits coverage as health insurance and coverage under a group health plan. The term 'resident' in the State-Based Universal Health Care Act of 2015 refers to an individual who is a citizen, national, or lawful alien residing in the State. The term 'Secretary' is defined as the Secretary of Health and Human Services for waivers related to specific provisions, and the Secretary of the Treasury for others. The Secretary of the Treasury, the Director of the Office of Personnel Management, the Secretary of Defense, and the Secretary of Labor have authority over waivers for specific provisions in federal health programs. The specified Federal health program includes Medicare, Medicaid, Children's Health Insurance Program, Federal Employees Health Benefits Plan, TRICARE program, Exchange under this subtitle, subsidies under section 1402, and tax credits under sections 36B and 45R of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new item in the table of contents after section 1332. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section, "Sec. 1332A. Waiver for State universal health care."
